comments.commentBody: I have always been mystified by the rarified ranks of the uber-execs who command these kinds of salaries in any industry.  It seems to be some kind of club like Skull & Bones that once you are admitted, you are set for life.  There is no success or failure that will affect your extravagant wealth one way or the other.  In fact, the rewards appear to be proportional to the damage you cause, as if the board is worried that you might feel embarrassed and need a few more millions of dollars to soothe your bruised ego.  OWS has shown that I'm not alone in feeling like a scullery maid at the Palace of Versailles -- grateful to be employed but clueless as to how my master's world actually works.

Thanks to Merryl Tisch and John King, Jr. increasing the number of meaningless standardized tests NYC students will have to take to graduate high school, more students will enter college in need of remediation. Tish and King need to be replaced by educators -- people who are experts in education and have  distinguished careers in education. So long as patronage determines who runs education in NY State, the current condition will exist.

My god, what are we doing to these poor kids? The fact that the number of children need remediation jumped a few years ago says everything -- the current focus on basic skills tests and teaching to the bottom of the class is robbing an entire generation of kids of a chance at life. We know what these kids need -- good teachers, paid a competitive wage; a rich, demanding curriculum; a safe classroom environment free of disruptive students and students who cannot do the work. Government takes us in the opposite direction.

Until we stop pretending that failure is success, education will continue to be a rather sad joke.  The Khan Academy approach of allowing experimentation but requiring mastery, should be the norm across all educational courses.  Moreover, vocational programs need to be aggressively introduced to high schools and given the same respect that college bound programs get.

This article simply reinforces what many of us suspect:
despite increased graduation rates, our high schools are graduating more and more ill prepared i.e. DUMBER !) students. God help us all!!!
Most college degrees in US are nearly meaningless status symbol which Anybody can get within 4, 5 or 6 years financed by student loan.

I think that this is great.

We certainly wouldn't want students to be proficient in math before they sign on the dotted line for the big fat loans that are needed for higher education.

After all, higher education isn't there to benefit the students. It is there to benefit the banks.

Now bow down, and kiss the ring.

Sincerely,

Your Almighty Banking Overlord

Here at Advocates for Abandoned Adolescents we do our absolute best to ensure that the voices of incarcerated youth and their families get allocated a responsible reform to America's Juvenile Justice.
Our Truth about youth Campaign seeks to hear from youth that have been prosecuted upto the age of 18yrs as an adult, as well as their family and friends, to collect their stories in order to understand their experiences, perspectives and recomendations for change in the Adult criminal Justice System.
Advocates for Abandoned Adolescents will use this information to identify patterns and trends that are worthy of further research that are specific to harmful effects on adolescents in the adult criminal justice system.
In addition, we seek to use your voices to communicate to policy makers and the public the real life impact that the Adult Criminal Justice System has on youth.
For we are endeavoured to bring the stories into brand new and diverse tapestry that paints the true circumstances and embodies the spirit of our approach to Juvenile Justice.

As someone who actually attends one of these aforementioned elite prep schools, though mine is a boarding school in New England, my opinions on homework and the prep school stress are quite mixed. Many students in their third and fourth years in of my prep school are going to bed way past midnight (often times pulling all-nighters) writing essays, studying for tests, and doing hours upon hours of homework. By the end of the term, students are sick, emotionally drained, and seriously sleep deprived. I've learnt, however, (to put it plainly) to suck it up.

Attending these elite schools is a privilege, one which I am constantly grateful for. I manage my work and clubs as much as possible,striving to do my best. I am learning more than I ever have before. The amount of homework is necessary in preparing me for college, and life after college (aka the real world). At the end of each week, I feel accomplished in knowing I have gotten through it. I feel that now I can face the challenges life brings me.

If Dalton or Horace Mann decrease their amount of homework, yes, some aspects of the school environment will be better. Maybe kids won't feel the need to pull all-nighters. This decrease in homework, however, will mark a substantial loss in the fundamental framework of the the schools' culture and reputation. If the students of today need standards to be lessened, where does that put the general intellect of our culture?

DC Lambert, the Times may be a national newspaper, but it's also a New York City newspaper with a prosperous readership, many of whom do send their children to these schools, often as a necessary alternative to the local public schools. It makes perfect sense that the Times would devote coverage to them.

As for the public schools, I wish that I could say as you do that they're doing well, but every indication is that they are getting progressively worse. If nothing else, the private schools are a reservoir of rigor in an increasingly dismal educational landscape.

Say what you will about excessive program loads at Dalton, the problem those kids face is nothing compared to the problems faced by another group discussed in today's paper, kids who arrive at City College without math skills that a child at Dalton or Horace Mann has mastered by age 12.

A professor told me a while back that of the students in his linear algebra class, only one was able to calculate the volume of a 2 x 2 x 2 cube. Try teaching the Cauchy–Binet formula to them. I feel for talented children who don't live in an upscale suburban district with top-notch public schools and can't afford private school tuition. What we are doing to our children, and to the future of our country, is nothing less than shameful.

GaryA@76 and Brown@72: Oh, please -- it's so obvious. You're still on a curve of constant bearing as you continue along the loxodrome, correct? Sooo ... that bearing is the constant direction you are always traveling in. If the loxodrome bearing is 45 degrees to the left (or right) of the meridian you're currently crossing, then that is the direction your shoes always point.

If you want to get specific, suppose you are in Tierra del Fuego and you want to walk south and into the sunrise while at the same time keeping to that 45-degree bearing to the meridians. You are then going southeast ... forever. (That is the orientation of my plots @65 if the target origin is the south pole.)

The criticism and sarcasm emanating from this article just proves the reporter is either naive, or hasn't been reporting very long.  In fact, he probably has no knowledge of Denver footbal history, as we saw the same thing when Elway first joined the Broncos, and he became one of the NFL's legends!  Elway wasn't that impressive when he started his NFL career, either!  Reeves managed him poorly at first!  However, Tebow was amazing today despite mismanagement!  Sure he was green in many ways during the first three quarters--this is his first NFL start, for crying out loud.  But isn't it probable that he was following his coach's calls?  Then, when it seemed they had nothing to lose, he was allowed to just play his own game, at which point he came through like the amazing gift he is? An entry level requirement, David.  Definitely necessary.  Not sufficient without it.  But the job demands much, much more.  If they can't perform at the ridiculously low level of challenge posed by the format of today's "debates," they are poor prospects indeed.

Since all the world's a stage, what you see and hear isn't all you get. When I listen to Republicans debate, I am reminded of Plato's admonition "Be as careful in the marketplace of ideas as you would buying bananas". Any one of them is only qualified to run a Banana Republic.

Without the debates, we might never know how voting into office Herman Cain or a Rick Perry or any of the other Republican candidates would make us into a world class joke as a nation. Let them have at each other.
Only a debate lets us know who's the wannabe emperor without any clothes.

The fact that Jefferson had poor rhetorical skills is beside the point. Jefferson did not have to make speeches on national TV or explain policy to millions of people. Today's presidents do. Perhaps Jefferson would not make the cut today. But who is to say whether Jefferson, who like every leader was a man of his time, would make an appropriate president in 2012?

What criteria would Mr. Dallek have us use to evaluate presidential candidates, if not their performance in debates? At least debates present the viewer with the actual candidates, as unvarnished as they can get in this PR-driven age, and not simply with more talking heads or proxy campaign aides. I would much rather judge a candidate by his or her onstage performance than by whatever ghost-written policy drivel they put together for newspaper op-eds or Twitter updates.
